faq1.question: What if my project doesn't fit a package?
faq1.answer: No problem! Our Custom/Retainer option is flexible. We'll scope your project, provide a detailed proposal, and work with you to find the right arrangement.

faq2.question: Do you require a deposit?
faq2.answer: Yes, we typically require a 50% deposit to begin work. The remaining 50% is due upon project completion. For larger projects, we can arrange milestone-based payments.

faq3.question: What's not included in these prices?
faq3.answer: Third-party costs like hosting, domains, stock photos, or premium plugins are not included. We'll discuss any additional costs upfront during scoping.

faq1.question: How long does a typical project take?
faq1.answer: Project timelines vary based on complexity. A landing page sprint takes 7-10 days, while a full MVP build takes 4-6 weeks. During our initial call, we'll provide a realistic timeline based on your specific requirements and priorities.

faq2.question: What's your design and development process?
faq2.answer: We follow a proven 4-phase process: Discover (understanding your goals and users), Design (wireframes and visual design with your feedback), Build (development with regular check-ins), and Launch & Grow (deployment and optimization). You'll have visibility at every step.

faq3.question: Do you work with startups or only established companies?
faq3.answer: We work with both! From early-stage startups validating ideas with MVPs to established companies looking to modernize their digital presence. Our packages are designed to fit different stages and budgets.

faq4.question: What technologies do you use?
faq4.answer: We specialize in modern web technologies: React, Next.js, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS for web; React Native for mobile apps. We choose the right stack for each project based on requirements, scalability needs, and your team's capabilities.

faq5.question: How do you handle revisions and feedback?
faq5.answer: Collaboration is built into our process. Each project includes defined revision rounds, and we use tools like Figma for design feedback and regular video calls to ensure we're aligned. We don't disappear—we communicate.

faq6.question: What happens after the project launches?
faq6.answer: We provide a thorough handover with documentation and training. If you need ongoing support, we offer maintenance retainers. Many clients continue working with us on iterations and new features after launch.

faq7.question: Can you work with our existing team or codebase?
faq7.answer: Absolutely. We regularly collaborate with in-house teams and can work within existing codebases. We're experienced in code reviews, documentation, and knowledge transfer to ensure smooth handoffs.

faq8.question: What's included in your pricing?
faq8.answer: Our pricing covers everything needed to deliver the project: strategy, design, development, testing, and deployment. There are no hidden fees. We'll provide a detailed scope before starting so you know exactly what you're getting. If you want to learn more about how website pricing is structured, check out our pricing article.

pricingPost.title: How Much Does a Website Cost in 2026?
pricingPost.subtitle: A complete guide to costs and factors that influence website pricing
pricingPost.intro1: In today's digital landscape, a strong online presence is no longer an advantage but a necessity for every business. One of the first questions that naturally arises is: how much does it cost to build a website and what budget should you reasonably plan for?
pricingPost.intro2: The truth is, there's no universal answer to the cost of creating a website. It depends on numerous factors and can vary widely – from approximately 250 € for a small, clean, and functional website, to over 10,000 € for complex digital solutions, large online stores, or fully customized platforms in 2026.
pricingPost.intro3: In this article, you'll find a detailed and practical guide to all the costs associated with building a website. We'll explore what influences the final price – the type of site, design and user experience, required functionalities, as well as additional elements like hosting, domain, SEO optimization, and maintenance.
pricingPost.intro4: Our goal is to bring clarity and transparency to every stage of the process, so you can plan confidently, avoid hidden costs, and make the right choice for your business.
pricingPost.intro5: Learn how website development pricing is structured in 2026 and establish a solid foundation for your successful online growth.
pricingPost.howPriceFormedTitle: How is website development pricing structured?
pricingPost.howPriceFormedText: The cost of building a website is not a fixed amount – it's built from several key components. Generally, costs can be divided into three main categories: one-time development investment, hosting, and domain.
pricingPost.oneTimeInvestmentText: This is the main expense paid at the start of the project. It covers the entire process – from the initial idea and planning, through design and development, to the moment the website is ready to be published online. Typically, this investment forms about 60–80% of the total project value.
pricingPost.uiUxText: This is where the visual identity of the website is created – colors, typography, element layout, and user journey. The goal isn't just for the site to look good, but to be easy to use and guide users toward a specific action – inquiry, purchase, reservation.
pricingPost.technicalText: At this stage, the website is functionally developed – pages, navigation, contact forms, and all necessary features are created.
pricingPost.cmsSites: CMS-based websites – faster to launch, with more limited flexibility;
pricingPost.customSites: Custom websites – fully developed according to individual requirements, with a higher price but full control over functionalities, security, and scalability.
pricingPost.hostingText: Hosting is the infrastructure where your website 'lives'. It ensures its availability and speed online. Usually paid on a monthly or annual basis.
pricingPost.domainText: The domain is the web address of your project. A well-chosen domain should be short, easy to remember, and connected to your brand.
pricingPost.blogTypeDesc: Suitable for content, articles, and expert publications. Usually with a lighter structure and lower budget.
pricingPost.portfolioTypeDesc: Ideal for specialists and creative professionals who want to showcase their work in a visually impactful way.
pricingPost.corporateTypeDesc: More complex structure, focus on trust, brand, and service presentation. Requires clear UX planning and professional design.
pricingPost.ecommerceTypeDesc: Price depends on the number of products, payment methods, user profiles, integrations with external systems, and sales logic.
pricingPost.newsTypeDesc: Requires good categorization, search functionality, high speed, and the ability for frequent publications.
pricingPost.customTypeDesc: Platforms for training, reservations, or internal systems – top-tier projects with individual logic and functionalities.
pricingPost.templateText: More economical solution using a ready-made structure with visual adaptations. Suitable for startups and projects with limited budgets.
pricingPost.customDesignText: All elements are developed specifically for the particular business. Higher investment, but significantly better brand positioning and user experience.
pricingPost.designNote: In 2026, design isn't just visual – it's a conversion tool.
pricingPost.functionalitiesText: Website features depend entirely on business goals:
pricingPost.functionalitiesNote: The more specific the needs, the more individualized the price becomes.
pricingPost.timelineTitle: How does timeline affect the budget?
pricingPost.timelineText: Short timelines almost always lead to increased costs – between 20% and 50%, because:
pricingPost.timeline3: the standard development process is compressed.
pricingPost.additionalCostsTitle: Additional costs that are often underestimated
pricingPost.contentText: Professional copywriting is not an expense but an investment. Quality text builds trust, holds attention, and improves conversions and SEO results.
pricingPost.seoText: SEO includes analysis, strategy, technical optimization, and content. This is a long-term investment that brings sustainable organic traffic and reduces advertising costs.
pricingPost.maintenanceText: Regular maintenance ensures security, quick response to problems, good Google performance, and stable website operation over time.
pricingPost.multilingualText: Suitable for businesses with international ambitions. Each language version requires its own structure and SEO optimization.
pricingPost.freelancerText: A freelancer is often more affordable in terms of price but requires more coordination on your part.
pricingPost.agencyText: A digital agency offers a complete team and strategy – design, development, content, and marketing working in sync.
pricingPost.investmentTitle: Why is a website an investment, not an expense?
pricingPost.investment5: builds long-term value and sustainable growth
pricingPost.investmentConclusion: Ultimately, a properly planned website doesn't just pay for itself – it becomes one of your business's strongest assets.
